Michigan Ongoing Health & Safety Training Refresher 2023
Section 3: Prevention & Control of Infectious Disease (Including Immunizations)

THE MOST COMMON REASONS WHY CHILDREN IN CHILD CARE GET SICK SO OFTEN?

Building on what you just shared, let’s review the most common factors that contribute to why children in child care get sick so often.

First Exposure

Many times a child’s first time in a group setting is when they are in child care. This often is their first exposure to certain germs, making them more vulnerable.

Not Enough Immunity

Infants and young children are not old enough to have received all the required doses of a vaccine to have built up a good immunity to resist all diseases.

Normal Behavior

It is normal for infants and toddlers to touch everything and put their hands in their mouth often.

Passing of Germs

Children in a group setting eat and play close together so germs are more easily passed around.

Poor Hygiene

Young children do not consistently follow good hygiene even when they are reminded frequently.

How Are Germs Spread?

Infectious disease management begins by looking at how germs are spread. We will address the most common ways that germs are spread.

  1. Contact with People or Objects:

    It could be through hands that touch the nose or eyes or cover a mouth during a cough. Also contaminated hands or drippy noses can touch toys and other surfaces. Many objects can absorb, retain, and transport germs.

  2. Fecal – Oral Route:

    Children in diapers can spread infections through microscopic amounts of a bowel movement. With typical diaper changing and toileting behaviors, hands, floors, toilets and faucet handles can become contaminated.

  3. Respiratory Route:

    Airborne droplets form when a person coughs or sneezes. People standing nearby someone who coughs, or sneezes can inhale these droplets.

  4. And, through Blood, Urine and Saliva:

    Some infections can be spread through contact of contaminated blood or mucous membranes like Hepatitis B. Routine vaccinations virtually eliminate the risk of these infections being spread.
